page.title: 12INTERVIEW WITH MRS. PUNTINS
page.content: Mrs. Puntins said she'd known the area for sixteen years. It had expanded a great deal and more houses have been built. The roads are just about the same, but transport has changed because there are many more cars and lorries coming up and down the streets. The two most useful modern inventions are television and central heating. Mrs. Puntins has one son and two daughters, and she has just become a great grandmother.The war affected her family quite a lot. Her three brothers came home safely but two cousins were killed and one nephew was a prisoner of war in a concentration camp for four years. Since Mrs. Puntins was a little girl she thinks family life has changed for the better. Entertainment used to be a jam sandwich and a bottle of pop.
